questions.text: A 58-year-old male, who had a myocardial infarction one week ago, presents to the emergency department holding a clenched fist over his chest. Which biochemical marker would be most useful in confirming reinfarction in this patient?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Preferred biochemical markers due to their sensitivity and specificity.
  • ↳ Preferred biochemical markers
  • ↳ Criteria for ACS: Requires rise and/or fall in biomarker values, with at least one value above the 99th percentile upper reference limit.
  • ↳ Criteria for ACS:
  • ↳ Troponin T (cTnT) and Troponin I (cTnI ) increase significantly after STEMI.
  • ↳ Troponin T (cTnT)
  • ↳ Troponin I (cTnI
  • ↳ Can detect concentrations <1 ng/L in non-ischemic conditions.
  • ↳ <1 ng/L

  • ↳ Troponin levels:
  • ↳ Increase within 3-6 hours. Peak at around 36 hours. Remains elevated for 7-10 days after STEMI.
  • ↳ Increase within 3-6 hours.
  • ↳ Peak at around 36 hours.
  • ↳ Remains elevated for 7-10 days after STEMI.

Causes of elevated Serum Troponin other AMI

Cardiorespiratory Causes

Non-Cardiorespiratory Causes

  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Aortic dissection
  • Acute pulmonary edema
  • Tachyarrhythmias
  • Myocarditis/Myopericarditis

  • End-stage renal failure

questions.text: A 74-year-old patient comes to the emergency department with complaints of intermittent dizziness and lightheadedness. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed, as shown below. Based on the ECG findings and the clinical scenario, what type of atrioventricular block is most likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
2:1 Atrioventricular Block

About
  • 2:1 AV block occurs when every other P wave is not conducted to the ventricles, resulting in missed QRS complexes.
  • It can arise from either the AV node (nodal) or the His-Purkinje system (infranodal).

Types
  • Nodal (Type I - Wenckebach): Results from impaired conduction in the AV node, which can be influenced by sympathetic and parasympathetic tone. Characterized by progressively prolonged PR intervals before a dropped beat; usually benign.
  • Infranodal Block (Type II): Indicates a conduction defect in the His-Purkinje system, where interventions affecting the AV node will not alter the block. It is less affected by autonomic interventions. PR interval remains normal with a dropped beat; often requires a permanent pacemaker.

ECG Features
  • Every other P wave is not followed by a QRS complex.
  • In Type I, the PR interval is progressively prolonged, and the QRS complex is narrow.
  • In Type II, the PR interval is normal, and the QRS complex is prolonged.
  • A narrow QRS with Type I suggests AV nodal block, while a wide QRS indicates infranodal involvement.

Diagnostic Maneuvers
  • Carotid Sinus Massage/Adenosine: Slows the sinus rate, potentially unmasking PR interval changes indicative of Type I.
  • Atropine Administration: Enhances AV conduction; can resolve Type I block.
  • Exercise Testing: Also enhances AV conduction, potentially eliminating Type I block.

Treatment
  • Type II block typically requires implantation of a permanent pacemaker.
  • In cases of His-Purkinje disease, atropine may worsen the degree of block.

questions.text: A 72-year-old female with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with severe chest pain for 1 hour. Her ECG shows ST-elevation indicating a STEMI. She has a blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg and a history of active peptic ulcer disease. What is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?

A 50-year-old man comes to your clinic for a routine check-up. He has no significant past history, exercises regularly, and reports no chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, and his pulse rate is 75 beats per minute and regular. You perform an ECG as part of the screening, shown below.  What is the most likely finding based on this ECG?
questions.explanation:
Component

Cause

Normal Duration and Size

P wave

Atrial depolarization is initiated by the SA node.
  • 0.08–0.11 seconds
  • 2–2.75 small boxes
  • <2.5 mm (0.25 mV) in amplitude/ height
  • <0.12 sec (120 msec or 3 small boxes) in width

PR interval

Time from onset of atrial depolarization (P wave) to onset of ventricular depolarization (electrical impulse passing through AV node)
  • 0.12–0.20 seconds
  • 3–5 small boxes

Q wave

Initial depolarization of the interventricular septum, directed from left to right.
  • <0.04 seconds
  • <1 small box
  • Depth: <1/4 of R wave or ~1–2 mm (<0.5 small boxes)

QRS complex

Ventricular depolarization - the time taken for the electrical impulse to spread through the ventricles.
  • <0.10 seconds
  • <2.5 small boxes in width
  • Height: 5–30 mm (1–6 big boxes)

QT interval

Time from the start of ventricular depolarization to the end of ventricular repolarization.
  • Duration depends on HR.
  • HR inversely proportional QT length. Rate-corrected (QTc) 330–350 msec
  • ~11 small boxes

ST segment

Represents the early part of ventricular repolarization. It is isoelectric (flat).
  • 0.08–0.12 seconds
  • 2–3 small boxes
  • Normally isoelectric (flat), deviations >1 small box indicate pathology

T wave

Represents the later stage of ventricular repolarization.
  • <0.04 seconds
  • 2.5–6.25 small boxes
  • Height: Varies. Normally <5 mm (1 big box) in limb leads, <10 mm (2 big boxes) in precordial leads

U wave

Unknown origin; possibly related to repolarization of Purkinje fibers or ventricular walls.
  • Not always measurable

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with a one-month history of mild exertional dyspnea. She denies chest pain but has noticed some occasional palpitations. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg and regular heart sounds. You order an ECG, which is shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis based on this ECG?
questions.explanation:
Lead

Normal Axis

Left Axis Deviation (LAD)

Right Axis Deviation (RAD)

Lead I

Positive (R wave > S wave)

Positive (R wave > S wave)

Negative (S wave > R wave)

Lead II

Positive (R wave > S wave)

Negative (S wave > R wave)

Positive (R wave > S wave)

Lead III

Positive (R wave > S wave) or isoelectric

Negative (S wave > R wave)

Positive (R wave > S wave)

Lead aVF

Positive (R wave > S wave)

Negative (S wave > R wave)

Positive (R wave > S wave)

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with palpitations and lightheadedness. He has no significant past medical history and is otherwise healthy. After a thorough examination, an ECG is obtained.  Based on the patient’s presentation and the findings of the ECG, what is the most likely diagnosis?
A 25-year-old male presents with recurrent palpitations and dizziness. An ECG of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding this patient's diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: He is at risk for pre-excited atrial fibrillation leading to dangerously fast ventricular rates

options.label: B
options.text: The accessory pathway is the Bundle of James, facilitating rapid conduction.

options.label: C
options.text: The ECG shows a short PR interval, normal QRS, and no delta wave

options.label: D
options.text: Adenosine is contraindicated in this condition

questions.correct_answer: A. He is at risk for pre-excited atrial fibrillation leading to dangerously fast ventricular rates
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome

Lown-Ganong-Levine (LGL) Syndrome

Pathology
  • Accessory pathways (APs) known as the Bundle of Kent are the abnormal tissue bands connecting the atria and ventricles. (Option B ruled out)
  • They allow conduction outside the AV node, either antegrade or retrograde (in concealed APs), bypassing the normal AV conduction system.
  • Present from birth, they result from incomplete partitioning of the atrium and ventricle by the fibrous AV rings.
  • Associated with Ebstein’s anomaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, PRKAG2 mutations, Danon’s disease, and Fabry’s disease.
  • Accessory pathway connects to ventricular myocardium.
  • LGL is a type of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) characterized by a short PR interval and a normal QRS duration.
  • It involves an accessory pathway called the Bundle of James that allows rapid conduction between the atria and ventricles, often linked to the atrioventricular (AV) node.
  • Accessory pathway bypasses the normal pathway and connects to BOH.

Clinical Features
  • Common arrhythmias include narrow-complex paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), wide-complex tachycardias, and rarely, sudden death.
  • Tachycardia may develop due to re-entry circuits, causing orthodromic or antidromic AV re-entry tachycardias (AVRT).
  • Pre-excited atrial fibrillation (AF) can occur, leading to a dangerously fast ventricular rate, syncope, or collapse, requiring urgent treatment.
  • Patients may experience episodes of palpitations, dizziness, or syncope.
  • Symptoms can vary in frequency and intensity; some may have mild symptoms while others experience significant distress.
  • Episodes may be triggered by stress, caffeine, or exertion.

ECG Features
  • Short PR interval (<0.12 s), wide QRS complex, and delta wave (slurred upstroke of the QRS). (Option C ruled out)
  • QRS and delta wave morphology depend on the AP location:
    • Right-sided AP: LBBB pattern (lead V1).
    • Left-sided AP: RBBB pattern (lead V1), negative delta wave in aVL (can mimic lateral wall infarction).
    • Posteroseptal AP: Negative delta wave in leads III and aVF (mimicking inferior wall infarction).
  • Preexcitation may disappear during exercise.
  • Short PR interval (typically less than 120 ms).
  • Normal QRS complexes (narrow QRS).
  • The absence of a delta wave (unlike in Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome).
  • May show tachycardia during episodes of SVT, often with a regular rhythm.
 

Treatment
  • Acute management: Carotid sinus pressure or intravenous adenosine can terminate the tachycardia. (Option D ruled out)
  • For pre-excited AF, urgent DC cardioversion is recommended due to the risk of collapse or death.
  • Definitive treatment: Catheter ablation is first-line and curative in most cases.
  • Medications: Flecainide or propafenone can be used as alternatives but are less preferred.
  • Avoid digoxin, verapamil, and amiodarone due to adverse effects on AP conduction.
  • Acute Management:
    • Vagal maneuvers (e.g., Valsalva maneuver) can terminate SVT episodes.
    • Adenosine may be used for acute termination of tachycardia.
  • Chronic Management:
    • Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers may be prescribed for prevention.
    • Catheter ablation can be considered in cases of recurrent or symptomatic episodes.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine follow-up. She has a history of mild hypertension, which is well-controlled with medication. She reports no symptoms such as palpitations, dizziness, or chest pain. An ECG of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.explanation:
First Degree AV Block

Pathology
  • First-degree AV block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>0.20 seconds) without disruption of conduction from atria to ventricles.
  • The delay typically occurs in the AV node, but may also involve the atria, His bundle, or Purkinje fibers.

Etiology
  • Commonly attributed to increased vagal tone in younger patients.
  • In older patients, often due to fibrotic changes in the cardiac conduction system.
  • Other causes include coronary heart disease, myocardial infarction, electrolyte abnormalities, inflammation, infections, certain drugs, infiltrative diseases, collagen vascular diseases, and idiopathic degenerative diseases.
  • Lymes disease, Chagas disease, Diphtheria, Rheumatoid arthritis, Scleroderma.

Clinical Features
  • Usually asymptomatic; patients are often unaware of the condition until discovered on an ECG.
  • In cases where the PR interval exceeds 0.30 seconds, symptoms may resemble "pacemaker syndrome," including dyspnea, malaise, lightheadedness, and chest pain.

ECG Features
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by a PR interval greater than 0.20 seconds on an ECG.
  • PR interval can be marked (>0.30 seconds) in some cases, and P waves may appear within preceding T waves.

Treatment
  • Generally, no treatment is required; routine observation is sufficient.
  • Pacemaker placement may be considered for symptomatic patients with PR interval >0.30 seconds or those with coexisting heart disease.
  • No antiarrhythmic medications are indicated, and surveillance with routine ECGs is recommended to monitor for worsening.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of fatigue and occasional lightheadedness. He has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease. During the examination, he describes episodes of near-syncope. The physician performs an ECG to evaluate his symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Mobitz Type I (Wenckebach)

Mobitz Type II

Pathology
  • Progressive prolongation of PR interval until dropped beat.
  • PR interval longest before dropped beat.

Constant PR interval until a P wave is not followed by a QRS complex.

Etiology

Normal variant; high vagal tone; inferior ischemia; medication toxicity; post-surgery.

Associated with structural heart disease; myocardial ischemia; fibrosis.

Clinical Features

Often asymptomatic;

May cause syncope or lightheadedness.

Symptoms include fatigue, dyspnea, chest pain;

Can progress to complete heart block.

ECG Features

PR interval progressively lengthens before a dropped beat.

Constant PR interval;

May have widened QRS complex.

Treatment

Usually no treatment needed; may use atropine if symptomatic.

Requires immediate pacing; often necessitates a permanent pacemaker.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe fatigue, dizziness, and episodes of syncope. His medical history includes hypertension and a prior myocardial infarction. ECG of the patient is given below. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Third-Degree Atrioventricular Block

Pathology
  • Complete loss of communication between the atria and ventricles.
  • SA node activity continues independently, but impulses do not reach the ventricles.
  • Atrial and ventricular activities are completely dissociated.

Etiology
  • Common causes include idiopathic fibrosis, structural heart disease, acute ischemia, medication toxicity, and post-surgical effects.
  • Associated conditions: Lyme disease, collagen vascular disorders, and myocardial infarction (especially inferior wall MI).
  • Risk factors include diabetes, hypertension, and prior cardiovascular diseases.

Clinical Features
  • Symptoms may include fatigue, chest pain, shortness of breath, and syncope.
  • Patients often exhibit bradycardia and may show signs of hemodynamic instability.
  • Physical exam may reveal cannon A-waves due to simultaneous atrial and ventricular contractions.

ECG Features
  • Characterized by complete atrioventricular dissociation.
  • The atrial rate is faster than the ventricular rate.
  • ECG shows independent P waves and QRS complexes with no relationship between them.
  • P-P interval and R-R interval is constant but there is no synchrony between P-R.

Treatment
  • Initial management may include intravenous atropine.
  • Patients typically require pacing, either temporary (transcutaneous or transvenous) or permanent pacemaker placement.
  • Urgent consultation with cardiology and electrophysiology is advised for further management.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest pain and is suspected of having an acute myocardial infarction (MI). Which of the following imaging techniques would provide the most accurate diagnosis of the MI?

A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath for the past 2 hours. On examination, his pulse is irregularly irregular with a rate of 140 beats per minute. An ECG of the patient is given below. CHA2DS2-VASc score calculation shows a score of 3. Which of the following statements about his condition is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: The irregular pulse is due to abnormal atrial firing and re-entry circuits

options.label: B
options.text: The atrial rate is likely 300 beats per minute with a 2:1 AV block.

options.label: C
options.text: Anticoagulation is recommended to reduce stroke risk.

options.label: D
options.text: Beta-blockers and digoxin are the first-line rhythm and rate control agents respectively.

questions.correct_answer: B. The atrial rate is likely 300 beats per minute with a 2:1 AV block.
questions.explanation:
Atrial Fibrillation

Features
  • Characterized by abnormal automatic firing and multiple re-entry circuits. (Option A ruled out)
  • Atria beat rapidly and ineffectively; ventricles activated irregularly
  • Produces an "irregularly irregular" pulse
  • Palpitations, syncope, and breathlessness can be present
  • Asymptomatic AF: Can present as systemic embolism and stroke

ECG Features
  • QRS Complexes: Irregular but normal
  • P Waves: Absent; baseline may show irregular fibrillation waves
  • Ventricular Rate:
    • Fast at onset (120-160 beats/min)
    • Slower in chronic AF due to medication effects and AV nodal fatigue

Management

Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation

  • First-line Therapy: Beta-blockers are effective in patients with CAD, hypertension, and heart failure. (Option D ruled out)
  • Class Ic Drugs: Propafenone or flecainide to prevent episodes (not for patients with CAD or LV dysfunction).
  • Class III Drugs:
    • Amiodarone: Most effective but with significant side effects; used when other treatments fail.
    • Dronedarone: Alternative to amiodarone; contraindicated in heart failure.
  • Rate Control: Digoxin and verapamil for AV node conduction slowing, but not for AF prevention. (Option D ruled out)
  • Catheter Ablation: Considered for patients with drug-resistant AF; prevents AF in ~75% of cases but may have complications.

Persistent Atrial Fibrillation

  • Rhythm Control:
    • Cardioversion: Electrical or pharmacological (e.g., intravenous flecainide or amiodarone).
    • Timing: Immediate if AF <48 hours; anticoagulation required if AF ≥48 hours.
    • Prophylactic Amiodarone: To reduce recurrence risk.
  • Rate Control:
    • Medications: Digoxin, β-blockers, or rate-limiting calcium antagonists (verapamil, diltiazem).
    • Combination Therapy: Digoxin with β-blockers; avoid combining calcium antagonists with β-blockers.
    • Pace and Ablate: Permanent pacemaker with AV nodal block for symptomatic AF.

Thromboprophylaxis

  • Anticoagulation: Required for stroke prevention due to blood stasis in the left atrium.
    • Warfarin: INR target of 2.0–3.0; start 4 weeks prior to cardioversion.
    • DOACs: Rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban, and dabigatran as alternatives to warfarin; no monitoring needed.
  • Risk Assessment:
    • CHA2DS2-VASc Score: For stroke risk; anticoagulate if score ≥2. (Option C ruled out)
    • HAS-BLED Score: For bleeding risk; monitor patients with score ≥3.
  • Aspirin: Not recommended due to low efficacy in preventing embolic stroke.

CHA2DS2-VASc stroke risk scoring system for AF

Points

Parameters

Score

C

Congestive heart failure

1

H

Hypertension history

1

A2

Age (≥75 years)

2

D

Diabetes mellitus

1

S2

Previous stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA)

2

V

Vascular disease

1

A

Age (65-74 years)

1

Sc

Sex category (female)

1
 

Maximum total score

9 points

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with sudden onset palpitations. ECG is taken and given below. It shows a narrow complex tachycardia at 180 bpm. The postgraduate successfully terminates the arrhythmia using the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following best describes the primary mechanism by which this maneuver terminates the arrhythmia?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct stimulation of the sinoatrial node

options.label: B
options.text: Increased sympathetic tone to the heart

options.label: C
options.text: Transient block in AV node conduction

questions.correct_answer: C. Transient block in AV node conduction
questions.explanation:
Acute termination:
  • Vagal maneuvers (e.g., Valsalva, carotid sinus massage)
  • If vagal maneuvers fail, IV adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment: 6 mg - 12mg fast iv push.
  • Alternative drugs: verapamil, diltiazem, or beta-blockers
  • Synchronized cardioversion for hemodynamically unstable patients

Long-term management:
  • Catheter ablation: Often curative, especially for AVNRT and AVRT
  • Pharmacological therapy:
    • Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers for prevention
    • Class IC or III antiarrhythmic drugs in selected cases
  • Patient education on performing vagal maneuvers

Lifestyle modifications:
  • Avoid triggers (e.g., caffeine, alcohol, stress)
  • Regular exercise
  • Adequate sleep

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of prior myocardial infarction presents to the emergency department with severe palpitations, dizziness, and chest pain. His blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, and he appears diaphoretic and confused. An ECG shows wide QRS complexes, a regular rhythm, and a ventricular rate of 160 bpm. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with palpitations and lightheadedness. She has a history of hypertension and is on multiple medications. Her ECG is given below:  Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?

A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with palpitations and lightheadedness. His ECG shows a rapid, regular rhythm with a rate of 150 beats per minute as shown below  Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with this ECG finding?
questions.explanation:
Type of QRS Complex

Associated Conditions

Narrow QRS complex

AV nodal re-entrant tachycardia, AV reentrant tachycardia (Orthodromic)

Broad QRS complex

Ventricular tachycardia, Torsades de Pointes

Delta Wave

Wolf-Parkinson-White syndrome

J wave/Osbourne wave

Hypothermia

Epsilon wave

Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain. His ECG is given below.  Which of the following is NOT a common cause of changes seen in the ECG above?
questions.explanation:
ST elevation

ST depression
  • Acute myocardial infarction (Option A ruled out)
  • Early repolarization (normal variant) 
  • Pericarditis (Option B ruled out)
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy in V1–V3 leads (Option C ruled out)
  • Left bundle branch block in V1–V3 leads.
  • Ventricular aneurysm
  • Myocardial ischemia
  • Hypokalemia 
  • Digitalis effect 
  • Reciprocal changes in acute MI
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy in V5, V6, I, aVL leads. 
  • Left bundle branch block in I, aVL, V5–V6 leads.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with fatigue, confusion, and muscle weakness. The ECG is attached below.  Which of the following would be the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Abnormality

Causes

ECG Findings

Prolonged QT Interval
  • Congenital Long QT Syndrome
  • Acquired causes:

- Electrolyte disturbances (hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia) (Option A and Option D ruled out)

- Medications (antiarrhythmics, antipsychotics, antibiotics)

- Bradycardia

- Hypothyroidism (Option C ruled out)

- Hypothermia

- Myocardial ischemia
  • QTc > 440 ms in males or > 460 ms in females
  • T wave abnormalities (broad, notched, or low amplitude)
  • Increased risk of Torsades de Pointes

Shortened QT Interval
  • Congenital Short QT Syndrome
  • Acquired causes:

- Hypercalcemia (Option B)

- Hyperkalemia

- Hyperthermia

- Acidosis

- Digoxin effect (not toxicity)

- Increased sympathetic tone
  • QTc < 330 ms
  • Tall, peaked T waves
  • Absent or very short ST segment
  • Increased risk of atrial and ventricular arrhythmias

QT Dispersion
  • Myocardial ischemia or infarction
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy
  • Electrolyte imbalances
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Difference between the longest and shortest QT interval > 50 ms across all 12 leads
  • Associated with increased risk of ventricular arrhythmias

T Wave Alternans
  • Severe heart disease
  • Electrolyte imbalances
  • Long QT syndrome
  • Acute myocardial ischemia
  • Beat-to-beat alternation in T wave amplitude, morphology, or polarity
  • May be visible or microscopic (requiring special ECG processing)
  • Associated with increased risk of sudden cardiac death

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department in acute distress. He is diaphoretic, tachycardic, and complains of severe chest pain. His ECG is given below. Given the patient's condition, what is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Atrial Flutter

Features
  • Atrial flutter is characterized by a large re-entry circuit, usually within the right atrium, encircling the tricuspid annulus originating from the cavotricuspid isthmus.
  • The atrial rate is approximately 300 beats per minute.
  • It is typically associated with 2:1, 3:1, or 4:1 AV block, resulting in ventricular rates of 150, 100, or 75 beats per minute.

ECG Features
  • The ECG shows saw-tooth flutter waves, often referred to as "F-waves."
  • With a 2:1 AV block, flutter waves may be buried in QRS complexes and T waves, making them difficult to identify.

Diagnosis
  • Atrial flutter should be suspected in narrow-complex tachycardia at a rate of 150 beats per minute.
  • Carotid sinus pressure or intravenous adenosine may help reveal flutter waves by temporarily increasing the degree of AV block.

Management

1. Rhythm Control:

  • Acute Management:
    • Hemodynamically Unstable Patients: Synchronized cardioversion (Option D).
    • Stable Patients:
      • Electrical cardioversion (if no intracardiac thrombus).
      • Pharmacological cardioversion:
        • Antiarrhythmic drugs:
          • Amiodarone (Option A ruled out)
          • Class IA: Procainamide, Quinidine, Disopyramide
          • Class IC: Flecainide, Propafenone
        • Calcium Channel Blockers: Verapamil, Diltiazem
        • Beta-Blockers: Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol
  • Long-Term Management:
    • Radiofrequency catheter ablation of the cavotricuspid isthmus. (Option B ruled out)

2. Rate Control:

  • First-Line Agents:
    • Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., Verapamil, Diltiazem)
    • Beta-Blockers (e.g., Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol)
    • Digoxin (use cautiously due to toxicity). (Option C ruled out)
  • Goal: Heart rate < 110 beats per minute.

3. Anticoagulation:

  • Assess stroke risk using the CHADS2-VASC score:
  • Anticoagulation Recommendations:
    • 2 or more points: Strong recommendation for anticoagulation.
    • 1 point: Consider either aspirin or full anticoagulation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with chest pain. ECG is given below. Considering this presentation, which of the following conditions could be responsible for the observed ST elevations? Hyperkalemia Variant Angina Digoxin (Therapeutic doses) Left Ventricular Hypertrophy (LVH) Chronic Stable Angina
questions.explanation:
ST Elevation

ST Depression
  • Acute Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)
  • Prinzmetal Angina (Option 2)
  • Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB)
  • Brugada syndrome
  • Left Ventricular Hypertrophy (LVH) (Option 4)
  • Pericarditis
  • Benign early repolarization
  • Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy
  • Aortic Dissection
  • Hyperkalemia (Option 1)
  • Non-ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI)
  • Digoxin (Therapeutic doses) (Option 3 ruled out)
  • Chronic Stable Angina (Option 5 ruled out)
  • Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
  • Hypokalemia

questions.text: An elderly male with a history of cigarette smoking and hypertension develops chest pain after an evening walk. The pain is relieved after lying down for a few minutes. A treadmill stress test reveals ST-segment depression. What is the most likely cause attributed to this clinical presentation?

A 60-year-old male undergoes a treadmill ECG stress test and develops 2 mm of horizontal ST-segment depression after 8 minutes of exercise. He reports non-limiting chest pain (angina index = 1). What is his Duke Treadmill Score (DTS) and his risk category?
questions.explanation:
Risk

DTS

Interpretation

Low Risk

≥ 5

No need for further coronary angiography.

Intermediate Risk (Option C)

+4 to –10

May need further tests, such as myocardial perfusion scanning or coronary angiography.

High Risk

< –10

Requires further investigation with coronary angiography.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with chronic stable angina that has progressively worsened despite optimal medical therapy. He underwent myocardial stress testing, which indicated ischemia. What is the next best step in diagnosing the extent of his coronary artery disease?
questions.explanation:
Investigation

Indications

Limitations

Exercise Treadmill Test

Initial test for intermediate-risk patients without resting ECG abnormalities; used for risk stratification and diagnosis of CAD.

Non-diagnostic in patients with LBBB, LVH, paced rhythm, or digoxin use.

Stress Echocardiography (Option A)

Used in patients who cannot exercise or have resting ECG abnormalities; preferred for evaluating LV function and ischemia.

Image quality can be affected by obesity and COPD; technician-dependent.

Myocardial Perfusion Imaging (Option B)

Preferred for patients with prior revascularization, resting ECG abnormalities, or high risk of ischemia.

Expensive; exposes patients to ionizing radiation.

Cardiac Magnetic Resonance Imaging

Indicated for comprehensive assessment of myocardial function, perfusion, structural heart disease, and subendocardial ischemia.

Contraindicated in patients with metallic implants; long acquisition times.

Coronary Computed Tomography Angiography (CCTA) (Option D)

Alternative for patients with inconclusive ETT results or lower risk; also evaluates CABG patency and coronary artery anomalies.

May not detect all critical stenoses; exposes patients to radiation.

Coronary Angiography

Gold standard for definitive diagnosis of CAD in patients with confirmed ischemia or medically refractory angina.

Invasive, high cost,

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with chronic stable angina presents with worsening chest pain during routine activities. His current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, and atorvastatin, but his symptoms persist. ECG shows ST-segment depression in V5-V6, and coronary angiography reveals 80% stenosis of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. What is the most appropriate intervention?

options.label: C
options.text: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with drug-eluting stent (DES)

options.label: D
options.text: Refer for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)

questions.correct_answer: C. Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with drug-eluting stent (DES)
questions.explanation:
Medication Class

Function/Mechanism

Indications

Side Effects/

Contraindication

Nitrates

Sublingual nitroglycerin (0.4 or 0.6 mg)

Long-acting forms (oral, transdermal)
  • Systemic venodilation
  • Reduces LV end-diastolic volume and pressure
  • Releases nitric oxide (NO) to relax vascular smooth muscle
  • Angina relief
  • Preemptive use before activities
  • Improves exercise tolerance
  • Tolerance development
  • Headaches, dizziness

Beta-Blocker (Option A)
  • Reduces heart rate, arterial pressure, and myocardial contractility
  • Improves survival post-MI
  • Angina relief
  • Reduces mortality and reinfarction rates
  • Asthma
  • AV conduction disturbances
  • Severe bradycardia

Calcium Channel Blockers
  • Coronary vasodilators
  • Reduces myocardial oxygen demand and arterial pressure
  • Dihydropyridines (e.g., amlodipine) and non-dihydropyridines (e.g., verapamil)
  • Angina treatment when beta blockers are ineffective
  • Variant angina
  • Bradyarrhythmias
  • May aggravate LV failure

Antiplatelet Drugs
  • Aspirin: inhibits platelet activation
  • Clopidogrel 75mg: blocks platelet aggregation
  • Reduces coronary events in high-risk populations
  • Stent placement
  • Risk of bleeding
  • Gastrointestinal issues, allergies

Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) (Option C)

PCI involves balloon dilatation and stenting for symptomatic IHD with suitable stenoses in epicardial coronary arteries.

  • Indications:
    • Symptom-limiting angina despite optimal medical therapy.
    • Evidence of ischemia during stress tests.
  • Post-PCI Management:
    • Aspirin is administered indefinitely, and P2Y12 antagonists for 1-3 months.
    • Current-generation drug-eluting stents reduce restenosis but require prolonged dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT).

Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG) (Option D)

Involves bypassing obstructive lesions using internal mammary arteries, radial arteries, or saphenous veins.

  • Indications:
    • Safe with low mortality in patients without serious comorbidities and normal LV function.
    • Effective for patients with left main coronary artery stenosis, multivessel disease, or impaired LV function.
  • Outcomes:
    • Angina relief in ~90% of patients after complete revascularization.
    • Long-term survival benefits in specific populations, particularly those with diabetes or impaired LV function.

questions.text: What is the revascularization procedure of choice for triple vessel disease and left main coronary artery disease, respectively?

options.label: D
options.text: PCI with stenting; PCI with stenting

questions.explanation:
Condition

Preferred Treatment
  • Single or two-vessel disease (non-proximal LAD, non-left main)
  • High surgical risk (comorbidities)
  • Contraindication to surgery
  • Elderly patients (>80 years or frailty)

PCI (Percutaneous Coronary Intervention)
  • Multivessel disease
  • Proximal LAD involvement
  • Left main coronary artery involvement
  • In-stent restenosis (with DES in major arteries)

CABG (Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting)

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 30-minute episode of chest discomfort that occurred while she was watching television. She describes the pain as a tightness in his chest, radiating to her left arm. She has a history of diabetes and high cholesterol. An ECG reveals inverted T-waves. Which of the following investigations is considered the most crucial next step in evaluating her condition?
questions.explanation:
Investigations

  • ECG is the first and must investigation in this case, and it shows:
    • Hyperacute T-waves
    • Flat T-waves
    • Inverted T-waves (25% cases)
    • ST depression (25% cases)
    • Normal ST wave (50%)
    • Most commonly, sinus rhythm is seen in unstable angina
  • Blood investigations:
  • CBC, platelet count, metabolic profile
  • Troponin test for infarction (normal or slightly elevated)
  • Coagulation studies
  • Chest X-ray to rule out other conditions.
  • Cardiac stress tests: (Option C)
  • Walking treadmill stress test
  • Stress echocardiogram
  • Myocardial perfusion imaging (Option D)
  • Cardiac CT/MRI
  • Cardiac catheterization (Gold standard) (Option B)

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department with episodes of chest pain at rest that lasts for about 15 minutes and shortness of breath. The pain is central and radiates to the left arm and jaw. His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Investigations show normal enzyme levels. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient's condition?

A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with episodes of chest pain occurring at rest, particularly during the night. His symptoms are often triggered by emotional stress and are relieved by nitroglycerin. An ECG was performed and is given below. There is no elevation of cardiac markers. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following vessels is at the greatest risk of atherosclerosis, arranged from highest to lowest?

options.label: A
options.text: Popliteal arteries > Coronary arteries > Circle of Willis > Abdominal aorta

options.label: B
options.text: Coronary arteries > Abdominal aorta > Circle of Willis > Popliteal arteries

options.label: C
options.text: Abdominal aorta > Coronary arteries > Popliteal arteries > Circle of Willis

options.label: D
options.text: Coronary arteries > Circle of Willis > Abdominal aorta > Popliteal arteries

questions.correct_answer: C. Abdominal aorta > Coronary arteries > Popliteal arteries > Circle of Willis

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes presents to your office with chest discomfort at rest, jaw pain, and nausea. On examination, she appears anxious, with cool, pale skin. The symptoms occurred suddenly 2 hours ago and are getting worse. She has a 20-pack-year smoking history. An ECG shows multiple T wave inversions and ST depressions in contiguous leads, and lab reports show raised Trop-I. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 58-year-old man presents with chest pain similar to episodes he experienced in the past. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The ECG shows ST-segment depression <0.5mm, and his cardiac troponin levels are elevated. Using the TIMI risk scoring system, what is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Discharge with a referral for outpatient stress testing

options.label: C
options.text: Initiate high-dose atorvastatin and schedule for follow-up in one month

options.label: D
options.text: Administer sublingual nitroglycerin and start intravenous beta-blockers

questions.correct_answer: D. Administer sublingual nitroglycerin and start intravenous beta-blockers
questions.explanation:
Risk factors
  • Age ≥65 years
  • Known coronary artery disease
  • ST deviation >0.5mm on presenting ECG
  • Raised cardiac markers
  • ≥2 original episodes in the prior 24 hours
  • Prior angina
  • ≥3 CAD risk factors

Number of risk factors

Incidence of adverse cardiac events (%)

0/1

5

2

8

3

13

4

20

5

26

6/7

41

Medical management

Anti-ischemic therapy:

  • Sublingual glyceryl trinitrate/nitroglycerin:
    • DOC for unstable angina
    • For ischemic discomfort
  • IV beta-blockers (Atenolol, Metoprolol):
    • They reduce the oxygen demand of the myocardium
    • They relieve pain, reduce arrhythmias, and reduce short-term mortality
  • Verapamil and diltiazem:
    • Given if symptoms are not relieved by full dose beta blockers and nitrates
    • They decrease the heart rate
  • IV morphine sulfate or diamorphine:
    • For analgesia
  • Antiemetics like metoclopramide (For symptomatic relief)
  • Nifedipine or amlodipine (If chest discomfort persists)
  • Atorvastatin and other HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors: Reduces occurrence of MI and recurrences of acute coronary syndrome
  • Ezetimibe or alirocumab, evolocumab:
    • Given if unresponsive to full dose statins
    • They reduce LDL cholesterol and prevent further cardiovascular events

Antithrombotic therapy:

  • Antiplatelet drugs:
    • Cyclooxygenase inhibitor: aspirin
    • Platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor: clopidogrel

Anticoagulants:

  • Unfractionated heparin.
  • Low molecular heparin: enoxaparin.
  • Direct thrombin inhibitor: bivalirudin.
  • Synthetic factor Xa inhibitor: fondaparinux.

Invasive management
  • Done if the medical management fails and symptoms do not improve. (Option A)
  • Coronary arteriography must be done within 48 hours of presentation.
  • Coronary revascularization includes PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

NSTE-ACS

NSTEMI

STEMI
  • Non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome
  • Include both NSTEMI and unstable angina

Non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction

ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction

ST-segment elevation absent

ST-segment depression or T-wave inversions

Significant ST-segment elevation

Normal troponin levels (in unstable angina) or elevated (in NSTEMI)

Elevated

Elevated

Myocardial necrosis is present (NSTEMI) / absent (unstable angina)

Myocardial necrosis is present

Myocardial necrosis is present

High risk for myocardial infarction

Serious ischemia, further evaluation needed

Urgent reperfusion therapy required

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes at night with chest pain that started earlier that evening and has progressively worsened. She describes the pain as a burning sensation accompanied by a sour taste in her mouth, which began shortly after dinner. She has had similar experiences previously, but not as severe as now. Initial laboratory tests and an ECG show normal results. What is the most likely cause of this patient's chest pain?
questions.explanation:
Cardiopulmonary causes

Non-cardiopulmonary causes

Cardiac causes:

  • Myocardial ischemia
  • Pericarditis

Gastrointestinal causes:

  • Esophageal reflux
  • Esophageal spasm
  • Peptic ulcer
  • Gallbladder disease

Vascular causes:

  • Acute aortic syndrome
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Pulmonary hypertension

Neuromuscular causes:

  • Costochondritis
  • Cervical disc disease
  • Trauma or strain
  • Herpes zoster

Pulmonary causes:

  • Pneumonia or pleuritis
  • Spontaneous pneumothorax

Psychological causes:

  • Emotional and psychiatric conditions

History

Highly suspicious

Moderately suspicious

Slightly suspicious

2

1

0

ECG

Significant ST depression

Nonspecific abnormality

Normal

2

1

0

Age

≥65 years

45 to <65 years

<45 years

2

1

0

Risk factors

≥3 risk factors

1-2 risk factors

None

2

1

0

TOTAL

Low risk: 0-3

Not low risk: ≥4

questions.text: A 72-year-old man present with chest pain and shortness of breath. He has a history of coronary artery disease and underwent a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) two days ago. An ECG shows ST-segment depression, and initial cTn values are found to be normal. Later, the cTn levels rise to five times the 99th percentile of the upper limit. What is the diagnosis here?

  • ↳ tenfold increase in cTn values
  • ↳ If initial cTn values are above the 99th percentile URL, a 20% rise is needed, with final values exceeding ten times the 99th percentile.

Universal definition of MI

  • Myocardial injury is when there is evidence of elevated cardiac troponin (cTn) levels with at least one value above the 99th percentile upper reference limit (URL).
  • Myocardial injury can be considered acute if the cTn values rise and/or fall.

Types of MI

Type 1 MI (Option A)
  • It is defined when there is a rise and/or fall of cardiac troponin (cTn) with at least one value above the 99th percentile of the upper limit.
  • With at least one of the following:
    • Symptoms of acute myocardial injury.
    • New ischemic ECG changes.
    • Development of pathological Q waves.
    • Imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium or new regional wall motion abnormality consistent with ischemia.
    • Identification of a coronary thrombus by angiography, intracoronary imaging, or autopsy.

Type 2 MI (Option B)
  • This does not include the identification of coronary thrombus.
  • Develops secondary to another illness or process.
  • Possible mechanisms include:
    • Fixed coronary atherosclerosis
    • Coronary spasm
    • Coronary embolism
    • Coronary artery dissection
    • Sustained tachyarrhythmia
    • Severe bradyarrhythmia
    • Severe hypertension
    • Respiratory failure
    • Shock
    • Severe anemia or hypotension

Type 3 MI
  • Very rare, constituting 3–4% of all MIs.
  • Defined as death from probable cardiac causes.
  • Distinction from non-cardiac causes of sudden death is important.
  • Autopsy findings of fresh or recent thrombus in the infarct-related artery confirm Type 1 MI instead of Type 3 MI.

Type 4a MI related to percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)
  • Requires a fivefold increase in cTn values if initial values are normal.
  • If initial cTn values are above the 99th percentile URL, a 20% rise is needed, with final values exceeding five times the 99th percentile.

Type 4b MI
  • This is associated with a stent thrombosis.

Type 4c MI
  • Associated with focal or diffuse restenosis after PCI.
  • Defined by a rise and/or fall of cTn values above the 99th percentile URL.
  • Diagnosis aligns with the criteria for Type 1 MI.

Type 5 MI related to coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) (Option C)
  • Requires a tenfold increase in cTn values if initial values are normal.
  • If initial cTn values are above the 99th percentile URL, a 20% rise is needed, with final values exceeding ten times the 99th percentile.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of severe chest pain that radiates to his left arm. This pain started about 30 minutes ago while he was at rest. His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. An ECG has been performed and cardiac biomarkers are significantly elevated. What is the most likely cause of his presentation?

A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest pain radiating to his left shoulder, which did not relieve with rest. An ECG is conducted. What is the earliest sign of myocardial infarction that is most likely to be seen on the ECG?

A 65-year-old male patient with a history of coronary artery disease undergoes angiography, which reveals a thrombus in the right coronary artery (RCA). Based on this finding, which area of the heart is most likely to be affected by an infarct?
questions.explanation:
Coronary Artery Affected

Location of Infarct

Left Coronary Artery (LCA)
  • Anterior Wall MI (most common) (Option A ruled out)
  • Extensive Anterior Wall MI

Left Circumflex Artery (LCX)

Lateral Wall MI (Option B ruled out)

Left Anterior Descending (LAD)
  • Anterior Wall MI
  • Septal MI (Option D ruled out)

Right Coronary Artery (RCA)

Inferior Wall MI

Posterior Descending Artery (PDA)
  • Inferior Wall MI
  • Posterior Wall MI
